name: VonC
text:
a/ and d/: yes and no. Yes, a DVCS like Mercurial is a good fit for distributed development, but by nature, there is no more "writelock", since there is no one "central server" which would be notified each time you want to modify anything.  
You will [pull (or check incomings) regularly from the remote repo][1].

b/ no, this isn't how a DVCS works, since a branch is [no longer a copy of a directory][2].

c/ binaries are best kept outside a DVCS (since it will be cloned around, and binaries would make its size grow too fast)  
See "[How is Mercurial/Git worse than Subversion with binary files?][3]"


  [1]: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Pulling+Changes+into+a+Bitbucket+Repository
  [2]: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Branching+a+Mercurial+Repository
  [3]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6598700/how-is-mercurial-git-worse-than-subversion-with-binary-files/6599303#6599303
